Author: Malti#3948
Content: except for reduced sell pressure, does a halving has any other direct effect on price?

Author: ComputerGenie ğŸ‘´ğŸ¼ğŸ“¢#7004
Content: if the market follows cost-to-mine any, a halving will cause a good bump in price

Author: Malti#3948
Content: yes but the 'if the market follows' is just based on incentives need to outperform costs

Author: Malti#3948
Content: so the main driver in higher prices are the miners

Author: Malti#3948
Content: if same demand for halved supply is the case, then indeed bump in price is expected

Author: ComputerGenie ğŸ‘´ğŸ¼ğŸ“¢#7004
Content: miners are generally the drivers of lower prices, not higher

Author: Malti#3948
Content: but if the bump in prices makes for reduced demand as well

Author: Malti#3948
Content: how so ? @ComputerGenie ğŸ‘´ğŸ¼ğŸ“¢

Author: ComputerGenie ğŸ‘´ğŸ¼ğŸ“¢#7004
Content:
as a general rule, miners aren't in crypto for crypto
to that end, they play "hot potato" and dump ASAP -- selling causes price decline

Author: Malti#3948
Content: okay but if prices are high, then it's in their best interest?

Author: ComputerGenie ğŸ‘´ğŸ¼ğŸ“¢#7004
Content: There are many miners that mine for or hold for future gains, but my experience shows them to be in the minority

Author: Malti#3948
Content: they sell in order to fund their operations

Author: Malti#3948
Content: and make profit obviously

Author: ComputerGenie ğŸ‘´ğŸ¼ğŸ“¢#7004
Content: just holding back for higher is in their interest, but (again, generally speaking) miners will take $2 now instead of "maybe" $4 later

Author: ComputerGenie ğŸ‘´ğŸ¼ğŸ“¢#7004
Content: almost invariably if there's a large gap between buy and sell price, miners will race to the bottom instead of forcing buyers up
